Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2011 11:34AM MaryNY wrote: Hi Deb: I exactly what you are saying about agree with you about breast cancer awareness being a good thing. I too was diagnosed with a rare disorder. In my case it was idiopathic transverse myelitis and I was diagnosed after I suddenly became paralyzed to the waist over the course of two hours one bright September morning in 2008. I was fortunate to be diagnosed and treated quickly but was still recovering from that when I was diagnosed with breast cancer. I know what it's like to go to doctors who have never heard of transverse myelitis (tm). It was a factor in deciding on what type of chemo to do and each time I saw an oncologist, I had to educate them on the disease. There is no awareness of transverse myelitis and little to no research. Yet it can be a debilitating disorder which leaves one-third of patients as paraplegic and another one-third are left with permanent, life-changing disabilities. Even if one is in the "lucky" one-third that recover, most are left with some residual side effects. Although I was shocked when I was diagnosed with breast cancer, at least I was dealing with a disease that didn't require any explanation beyond those words, there are lots of sources of information, support, ongoing research. There are statistics to help in making decisions about surgery and treatment based on one's specific diagnosis. It was much easier than dealing with tm. Even if it involves pink ribbons in October, I do think awareness is a good thing. And yes, it's a marketing ploy too but I don't think we can do much about that.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 10:16AM MaryNY wrote: jb: If it has been two weeks since the Oncotype test was ordered, I would call Genomic directly and ask them when the results will be back. When I did that two weeks after I was told that my test was ordered, I found that my onc's office had messed up and the test hadn't even been ordered nor had the tissue samples gone out. When you call give them your wife's name and date of birth and they will tell you when they received the tissue sample and when the ordering physician can expect the result. If the test is complete, they will not give you the results directly. You must get them from the doctor. Genomic are great to deal with, very professional. Don't hesitate to call them. It typically takes 10-14 calendar days to get the results, that's including weekends, so if yours was ordered when they told you it was, it should be back now. It would be good to have the result before your next appt on Friday. Genomic Health - Tel: +1 (866) ONCOTYPE (866-662-6897)

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 11:58AM MaryNY wrote: jbaudit: your wife would be a candidate for the Oncotype DX test, since she is ER+ and node-negative. Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 07:09AM MaryNY wrote: Thanks Beth. My surgery date will probably be in two weeks. The last time I met the breast surgeon was just after I got a depressing MRI report. BS asked me to have MRI just in case there was anything else. She said always best to know as much as possible prior to surgery. I was devastated when the MRI reported four additional suspicious masses. One was right beside the confirmed tumor and so similar in description (spiculated) that they figured high likelihood of malignancy and termed it a "satellite lesion." BS ordered biopsies of the other three suspicious areas. At that time she discussed mastectomy with me. But then the biopsies came back negative. So as far as the MRI is concerned, the cancer is confined to the twin lesions in the upper outer quadrant of my left breast. I now realize that MRIs can give false positives but they can probably give false negatives too. Did you have an MRI prior to surgery or did the two tumors show up on a mammo or ultrasound? My confirmed tumor and the twin (probable tumor) are very close together -- just 1.5 cm between their centers according to the MRI. Maybe yours were further apart? Apparently two or more tumors in the same quadrant is termed multifocal so in some cases I suppose they could be quite far apart so a lumpectomy might not be feasible.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 09:50PM MaryNY wrote: Hi Sherri: I think my initial visit took less then an hour. On that visit I met first with the radiation nurse. She went over all my records and put them in order. She also took a detailed history. Then the onc came in. She reviewed all my records and told me how many treatments to expect. She also did a breast exam. She then passed me on to the head technician who set up the appt for the mapping/planning. That second visit was the longest and was about a week later. That was the most difficult as I had to lie still for so long. You might want to call the office to confirm the appt. That way you can ask how long to allow for the appt. I find it takes a lot of stress out of the situation when you have more of an idea what to expect. I have heard of someone who was charged a copay for every radiation visit but I think that's unusual. I had just started rads in late Feb when my insurance provider changed. The first insurance company covered radiation treatment 100% but with my current provider they pay 90% until I've reached my deductible, then they pay any balance at 100%. I still haven't been billed. I think most places bill by the month. When you go for your appt on Wed, you could ask them to check for you or your could call your insurance company directly.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 10:41AM - edited May 26, 2010 10:50AM by MaryNY My onc periodically tests for tumor markers in my blood. She doesn't do PET or CAT scans post chemo. So I suppose every onc is different in how they monitor their patients. The two I've been checked for are Cancer Antigen 125 (CA 125) and Cancer Antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3). CA-125 is primarily used to monitor therapy during treatment for ovarian cancer. CA-125 is also used to detect whether cancer has come back after treatment is complete. Series of CA-125 tests that show rising or falling concentrations are often more useful than a single result. This test is sometimes used to test and monitor high-risk women who have a family history of ovarian cancer but who do not yet have the disease. CA 15-3 is not sensitive or specific enough to be considered useful as a tool for cancer screening. Its main use is to monitor a person's response to breast cancer treatment and to watch for breast cancer recurrence. CA 15-3 is sometimes ordered to give a doctor a general sense of how much cancer may be present (the tumor burden). CA 15-3 can only be used as a marker if the cancer is producing elevated amounts of it, so this test will not be useful for all breast cancer patients.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 07:42PM MaryNY wrote: Thanks Sunshine: I gave the wig people the code 174.4 over the phone, but they told me that it needed to be specified on the prescription itself so I'll ask the onc for a new Rx when I see her tomorrow. I found: 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.0—Malignant neoplasm of nipple and areola of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.1—Malignant neoplasm of central portion of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.2—Malignant neoplasm of upper-inner quadrant of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.3—Malignant neoplasm of lower-inner quadrant of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.4—Malignant neoplasm of upper-outer quadrant of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.5—Malignant neoplasm of lower-outer quadrant of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.6—Malignant neoplasm of axillary tail of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.8—Malignant neoplasm of other specified sites of female breast 2009 ICD-9-CM Diagnosis Code 174.9—Malignant neoplasm of breast (female) unspecified site Since 174.9 is for "unspecified site" it could probably be used as a catch-all, but since in my case the tumor was in the upper-outer quadrant, then 174.4 is more specific. What I don't understand is why they don't need a code for hair loss instead. Because the wig is needed as a result of the hair loss which is not caused directly by the breast cancer but rather is a side-effect of the chemotherapy used to treat the cancer.

Mel: My doc didn't give me any specifics about arm exercises after SNB but I figured anything that helped increase the range of motion in my arms would be good. Use your good arm as a guide to see what your goal is. Best one for me was standing facing a wall, placing my hands flat against the wall, then walking up the wall with my hands. I put stickies on the wall showing how far I could go with each hand, could see a slight improvement every day and by three weeks had the same extension with both arms. You can do some exercises while seated at your desk or watching TV, just try raising your hands over you head and moving them up/down, forward/back, etc. Don't force yourself beyond the pain point. I didn't experience any swelling after the SNB. I would ask the BS or nurse about that.  Marie: I think you'll really enjoy the LGFB workshop. It really helped me begin to come to terms with the idea of hair loss as about half the women there had already been through that and came out smiling.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 03:23PM - edited Sep 10, 2009 03:45PM by MaryNY Virginia: Please don't go away. We are not saying we share the doc's opinions just reporting on them. If those of us in the US go the cold cap route, we are prob not going to have the support of nurses or doctors on that decision. While one is in the chemo room, I'm guessing you need someone to come and change the caps and unless you bring a helper, the nurses here likely won't see it as their job to help. It seems that in the UK, the Macmillan nurses encourage the use of cold caps. I'm really surprised that recommended treatment vary so much between the US and UK. You said earlier that you were on FEC and I figured that would be a viable alternative to what the first two oncs recommded in my case. So I read up on epirubicin vs. doxirubicin (Adriamycin) and find that in some studies epirubicin doesn't show as much cardiac toxicity as doxirubicin. But then I find that in the US, epirubicin costs 22 times more than doxirubicin, so insurance companies won't cover its use. The higher cost has something to do with the patents on the drugs and generic versions being available, I think. I'm going to ask the onc about it today and see what she says. I'm guessing the more widespread use of Taxotere vs. Taxol may be cost-related too. What a world, where cost dictates the treatment we get. When I started on my breast cancer journey, I was headed down the road to a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with DIEP flap based on the advice of the first surgeon I saw. Then I spoke to a breast surgeon in Ireland who advised me that was far too drastic. I saw two more breast surgeons here in the US who agreed that a lumpectomy was a better option in my case. There is a tendency here to do mastectomies where lumpectomies would do. The mastectomies seem to be an easy sell when accompanied by the promise of perky new reconstructed breasts. Yes, we are too US-centric on here. There are just more American members than others so that's going to be reflected in the threads. Anyway, Virginia, please don't go away. I'm sure I speak for all of us when I say we really like your perspective, your sense of humour and your warmth to everyone new who joins the group.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 01:38AM - edited Sep 11, 2009 02:46AM by MaryNY I went to get a third onc opinion today. She was very thorough in taking my history. Her recommendation was different to the other two. She said I should definitely avoid the drug Taxotere that the other two had recommended because of my medical history, as it can lead to neuropathy in up to 50% of patients. She said with my history of transverse myelitis, I might be more susceptible and she said she really didn't want to take a chance esp since there are other choices. Her recommendation is either (1) FEC*6 or (2) CAF*6. Her preference is FEC as epirubicin has less cardiac toxicity than Adriamycin. However, although epirubicin is widely used in Europe, it's not widely used in the United States because it's more expensive here so I'm wondering if my insurance company would approve it. If not, I'll go with Option 2. Next step is to have a MUGA test to see it's OK see how my heart would get along with the anthracyclines. She's also going to order the Oncotype DX. I thougth I wasn't a candidate for that test since I'm node positive. This will take about a week so will delay my chemo start date. I'm going back to see this doc the week after next by which time she should have the results of the two tests.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 08:18AM MaryNY wrote: Yep, hernies are horibble. Telling my brother today and he said "oh, you have the Johnnies." Say what? "yes, the Johnny Giles." He's given to talking in Cockney rhyming slang. I have been eating bulksome cereal - pinhead oatmeal somedays and Weetabix on the others. I think I tried Fiber One before and found it to be very sweet, but must take another look at that. In your case, wouldn't fiber help also? It would slow things down and also hold fluid so the stools would be bulkier and softer. Have you tried going bratty? BRATTY is an acronym for bananas, rice, applesauce, toast, tea and yogurt. These foods, especially when eaten together, can help to firm bowel movements. In the past, physicians recommended the BRAT diet only, which did not include tea and yogurt, but the BRATTY diet is now preferred given the beneficial qualities in yogurt.  About yogurt, on those days where I found it hard to eat, I tried Dan-Active. It comes in a nice small container and you can drink it down in a couple of gulps. It's a bit sweet for my taste, but it has those good bacteria which can be used to restore the intestinal flora.

About the yeast infection. I was wondering would eating yoghurt with live cultures help? Or maybe taking probiotics? That might help restore the intestinal flora. MN-Jeanne -- I wish I had a garden. I cancelled my appt with my onc yesterday because of this mess and now have an appt for next Tuesday and a back-up appt on Thursday, in case the results aren't in on Tuesday.  I'd love to hear others timelines for this test. If I have to wait more than a week, I'm planning to go to Ireland for a few days to see my mother. Once treatment starts, I'm guessing that air travel will be out because of the bugs and uncertainty over side effects. Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 11:59AM - edited Sep 16, 2010 01:39PM by MaryNY Carrol: If you hair is as long as shown in the photo, then it would be a good idea to get it cut into a shorter style. Some people shave their hair off soon after starting chemo to re-empt the fall, but I didn't have the courage to do that. I think it's important too to pick out a wig while you still have all your hair. The wig seller can help you choose one that is close to your own color and style. Emotionally, it will be easier for you to do this before you start chemo. You don't have to buy yet, just choose a wig and have them put it aside. Your insurance may cover part or the entire cost of the wig but you do need to get a prescription from the oncologist for a "head prosthesis." Oh, if you can find one nearby, go to a Look Good Feel Better session. They will help you with wig choices, scarf tying, etc. Follow the link and input your zipcode to find a session near you. I went before I started chemo but many of the women there were already half way through chemo and when I walked in I had no idea that some of them were wearing wigs. They looked great. It took some of the fear out of it for me.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2011 08:01PM MaryNY wrote: Chan_go_foill: I think people see a couple of issues with applying color too soon. First because the hair is so short, a lot of the color may get on the scalp and be absorbed through the skin. Second, because the chemo drugs are still in the hair shaft, they interact with the dye causing unexpected colors. I think one of the main complaints is brown colors coming out with a reddish tinge. Since you used black that shouldn't have been an issue. I'm curious about your screenname -- is it Scot's Gaelic? The "go foil" part looks like the Irish "go fóill" meaning "yet" or "for now."

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2010 05:28PM - edited Aug 22, 2010 01:14AM by MaryNY I'd never hear of the Brazilian Blowout process either. It seems it's a trademarked name. It's expensive, one person said she paid $400 plus tip to have it done. Consider safety issues too -- on the official website they say: "There have been no clinical tests performed on the safety of performing the Brazilian Blowout on pregnant women or women who are breastfeeding. As a result, we do advise against pregnant or breastfeeding women receiving the Brazilian Blowout treatment." On one of the blogs devoted to the process, a few users mentioned that they had eye irritation both during their salon visits and a couple of days afterward. There is also uncertainty among some users whether the product contains formaldehyde or glutaraldehyde. Even low levels of exposure to formaldehye can cause runny nose, sore throat, headache, itching, rash and irritated eyes. It is also a known carcinogen. Glutaraldehyde has similar effects. The company who market the products does not admit to them contained either formaldehyde or glutaraldehyde but apparently they do not make the ingredient list public so who's to say for sure what the active ingredient is. See the Allure article from Oct 2007 — Scared Straight. What I've read in a few minutes online persuades me that even if I could afford it, I would not want to risk using this process.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 06:19PM MaryNY wrote: hmh23: Cancer Antigen 15-3 is a tumor marker test. Normal Range: 0 - 36 Units/ml, so yours is fine at 14.6. My last result on this test was 15 Units/ml. That was in May, a month after I completed rads. CA 15-3 is a protein that is a normal product of your breast tissue, and it does not cause breast cancer. If a cancerous tumor (cells growing out of control) is present in your breast, though, your levels of CA 15-3 may increase as the number of cancer cells increase. Tumor cells will shed copies of the CA 15-3 protein, which can be measured by this blood test

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 01:24PM MaryNY wrote: Ok ladies, I was thinking of you all on Saturday when I went for a New Year's Day walk in the woods.  It was tough going trudging through the snow and in some places because of the way it drifted, it was up to my knees. But someone had walked the path ahead of me, which made it easier so I was able to step into their footprints. I figured that's like our journey here where the efforts of those who've gone before help those of us who come later. Anyway, I only met one person. I turned a corner and there he was... a solitary snowman. He was sporting some acorn buttons, a stick nose and acorn eyes. Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 06:00PM MaryNY wrote: Chan_go_foill. That's interesting about your name's origin. You have anglicized it, or made the spelling phonetic, right? There would have been no "h" in Irish in the 16th/17th century and I think the same was true of Scots Gaelic. In modern Irish (widely used 1960s onwards) the "h" is used to indicate the accent (buailte) over a consonant. So prior to that "Chan go foill"  would be written as "Ċan go fóill." Some of the letterforms would have been quite different too. The word "Ċan" is foreign to my ears, though it seems to be used in Ulster Irish.

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 12:43PM - edited Mar 27, 2011 12:44PM by MaryNY Good link Nichole. I really think it's wise to exercise caution when taking supplements.  Ladies, please don't overdo the supplements without checking with your doctor. In the US and Canada, many foods are fortified with folic acid, so it's unlikely that you would be deficient if you are eating a well-balanced diet. The reason mandatory fortification was introduced was to help address the incidene of NTDs (neural tube defects) such as spina bifida in children. If you take a supplement along with your fortified orange juice and fortified cereal/bread in the morning, you may be already getting too much before you even head out the door. This is an abstract from a scholarly article in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition in 2004 "An overwhelming body of evidence for a protective effect of periconceptional folic acid supplementation against neural tube defects (NTDs) led to mandatory folic acid fortification in the United States. The effectiveness of folic acid fortification in improving folate status has already been shown to be quite striking, with a dramatic increase in blood measurements of folate in the United States. Preliminary reports also suggest a significant reduction (≈15-50%) in NTDs in the United States. The success of folic acid fortification in improving folate status and in reducing NTD rates is truly a public health triumph and provides a paradigm of collaboration between science and public health policy. Although folic acid is generally regarded as safe, there continues to be concern that folic acid fortification may have adverse effects in subpopulation groups not originally targeted for fortification. In this regard, an emerging body of evidence suggests that folic acid supplementation may enhance the development and progression of already existing, undiagnosed premalignant and malignant lesions. Over the past few years, the US population has been exposed to a significant increase in folate intake, for which essentially no data on safety exist. The potential cancer-promoting effect of folic acid supplementation needs to be considered in carefully monitoring the long-term effect of folic acid fortification on the vast majority of the US population, who are not at risk of NTDs."  I know it's an earlier study. More recent studies are not entirely conclusive, but some countries (e.g., Ireland, Norway) have decided to err on the side of caution rather than introduce mandatory supplementation with folic acid.

Posts.Content: MaryNY wrote: I've been a long time on this BC journey. In the beginning I thought that based on diagnosis, the path ahead would be clearly defined and I wouldn't really have to make any decisions. How wrong I was. There were delayed tests, confusing test results, differing medical opinions all along the way. Today I'm faced with yet another fork in the road and coming here for advice. I was diagnosed with IDC in May. I had a lumpectomy in August. Tumor was 1.8cm, Stage IIa, Grade 2, 1/6 nodes, ER+, PR+, HER2-. I'm 53 and pre-menopausal. In the normal course of events, next step would be chemo, followed by radiation then hormonal therapy. I went to see three oncologists. I informed all three that I was diagnosed a year ago with an autoimmune disorder, transverse myelitis. I have recovered almost completely but am left with some residual numbness on the right side, which might suggest I would be more susceptible to neuropathy, which is a common side effect of the taxanes. The first onc suggested TC*6. The second onc suggested AC*4, then T*4. The third onc said she would avoid the taxanes. She put it bluntly saying she didn't want to see me come back in six months in a wheelchair. She suggested CAF or FEC. First she ordered three tests: MUGA scan, CYP2D6 and Oncotype DX. My MUGA score was low normal (51%), CYP2D6 showed IM (intermediate metabolizer) and Oncotype Score is 18. With an Oncotype Recurrence Score of 18, I think that means that the recurrence percentage is 12%. Or maybe that is just for node-negative women? The Oncotype report refers to the SWOG 8814 study and the accompanying graph showed almost no benefit of using CAF-T over using Tamoxifen alone when the patient had 1-3 postive nodes and had a recurrence score of 18. But the study only involved 367 patients and they were post-menopausal (whereas I'm pre-menopausal). I'm not aware of any other studies that look at Oncotype and recurrence in node-positve women. So the options suggested by the oncologist are: (1) CAF or FEC, but there is no guarantee of benefit, while I would suffer all the SEs. I'm concerned about cardiac toxicity. She would try to get insurance to cover FEC, as she said epirubicin has less cardiac toxicity than Adriamycin. (2) Skip chemo, do radiation followed by Tamoxifen for five years. The CYP tests shows I can metabolize Tamoxifen (3) Skip chemo, do rads followed by both Tamoxifen and Zoladex (goserelin). She said that Zoladex would put me straight into menopause and enhance the effect of the Tamoxifen. I asked about using the CMF regimen but she dismissed that idea. I didn't follow up with her reasoning on that. I'm in a dither. Should I have chemo or not? Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 05:58PM - edited Jun 20, 2012 03:46PM by MaryNY Dianarose: When you first had bc back in 2004, did they recommend tamoxifen? Yes, chemo won't prevent you developing another tumor down the road, but it should get rid of any cancer cells circulating around the body and thus prevent local or distant mets. And those cancer cells are sneaky buggers. Even for those lucky enough to have no lymph node invasion, there is still no guarantee that the cells haven't gone further afield. As for risk factors for breast cancer -- as one of the speakers said at a cancer survivors event I attended last week, the main risk factor is being a woman. About one in eight U.S. women (just under 12%) will develop invasive breast cancer over the course of her lifetime. As for family history -- I too believed the myth that most women with breast cancer have a family history of the disease. But the majority of women diagnosed with breast cancer do not have a family history of the disease.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 03:27AM MaryNY wrote: bevin: the first breast surgeon I saw commented on the fact that sometimes the cancer cells migrate from the breast to elsewhere in the body without leaving any detectable traces in the lymph nodes. If someone has a clean lymph node dissection, does not autmatically mean some cancer haven't migrated elsewhere. It's less likely but possible. Otherwise oncologists would not be prescribing chemo for the many women who have no lymph node involvement. Radiation is used to nix any cells remaining at the site of surgery and adjuvant chemo is used to get any stray cells elsewhere

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 01:37PM - edited Jul 15, 2010 01:40PM by MaryNY Chancesmom: I was really battered and bruised after having MRI-guided biopsies last year. I ended up with a large hematoma, which didn't dissolve for a couple of months. Do use lots of ice. It would be best not to put the icepack next to your skin. You can get gel packs in a kind of sleeve in places like Bed Bath and Beyond. It's easier to use a gel pack (which you can keep in the freezer) than to be messing around with crushed ice. Once the swelling goes down, it does help to massage the are where you have the hematoma to break it up. I would call the place where you had the MRI and ask them for advice too. In my case, the nurse who assisted in the first two biopsies didn't apply enough pressure after the biopsy to staunch the bleeding. Another nurse told me that was what led to the hematoma. I already had a diagnosis of IDC when I went for the MRI. The three suspicious areas biopsied via MRI all came back benign.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 08:50AM MaryNY wrote: Hi Timbuktu: I had a somewhat similar experience to you at MSKCC. I had four oncology consults. The fourth was at MSKCC. I really felt that I was getting the expertise of a whole team there. Because I was node-positive, the onc I met with insisted on chemo. Also, they asked for all my records and I mean ALL to review everything again. So instead of relying on reports as many oncologists do, the reviewed all imaging and pathology slides on which the reports were based. And they found a micromet in a second lymp node which had been missed in the original review. This didn't change my treatment plan but made me realize how thorough they are. Yes, the Oncotype DX test is new and I do think it's a useful tool for those who are otherwise having a hard time making a decision about chemo. When I was originally diagnosed, the breast surgeon told me that chemo was almost certainly part of my future even without positive nodes. She said cancer cells can be sneaky and get past the lymph nodes without leaving a trace.  I do think that if the cancer cells have already shown their tendency to stray by showing up in the lymph nodes (as in my case), then one can't be certain that they haven't traveled further afield. They will not show up on scans until it's too late. It would be a shame if you had to go all the way to NY to get your treatment of choice. Could MSKCC suggest somewhere in Chicago? and maybe work with you and the doctors there.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 05:04PM - edited Jun 20, 2011 05:05PM by MaryNY Minxie: I thought they would never go away either. I finished chemo in Feb 2010 and toward the end the night sweats were the worst. Then after rads I started Tamoxifen in April 2010, so that's just over a year ago. Then things got much worse. Things were even worse during the night with being woken constantly with night sweats but were pretty rough during the day too. My chillow was my constant companion for months. I keep it in the fridge and would put it on top of my pillow at night. I rarely get night sweats now and so have not used the chillow for weeks until last night when I used it rather then turn on the a/c. It's very effective. You might want to get one and at least it would give you relief at night. If you get a good night's sleep, you will also feel much better during the day. It's much better than flipping your pillow trying to find the cool side. I also got back to walking regularly. And this coincided with the lessening of the hot flashes. It might be a coincidence but walking is good for us anyway. I have another homemade item that helps me with the night sweats. I made a rice-filled neck pillow. I just took a knee-high sock, filled it with rice and knotted off the end. I keep this in the freezer. It will stay cold for a few hours. Mine is not overfilled so I usually grip it in the middle, let the rice fall to the two ends, then twist, place it on my pillow and rest my head so that it cradles my neck. It feels great!  My night sweats and hot flashes are not gone completely but they are much less frequent. They did make me so miserable last summer. I just hope they don't come back again with a vengeance.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 03:20AM - edited Sep 30, 2011 06:01AM by MaryNY Kay: about the comment you made above about triple negative bc. Those women would not be given hormonal therapy. The Oncotype DX test presumes that the women tested will be given hormonal therapy and the predicted recurrence rate is based on that assumption -- so no, it doesn't apply to triple negative bc. I think hormonals are almost always recommended for ER+ bc unless there are medical reasons for not using them or their use is not well-tolerated by the patient.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 11:47AM - edited Jun 27, 2009 08:18AM by MaryNY I don't really understand why they don't to the biopsy first. I had a biopsy on a mass that showed up in both ultrasound and mammogram. It turned out to be malignant. Before scheduling surgery, the BS asked that I have a breast MRI "just in case there's anything else there." I had the MRI four weeks ago. To my horror, it identified four additional suspicous areas. One was close to and similar in description to the original tumor so that will be removed anyway. Biopsies were ordered for the other three. I had to wait three long weeks for those biopsies and was convinced that both breasts were riddled with cancer. I got the results two days ago -- all three are benign. So I'm just telling you this to let you know that breast MRIs can give a lot of false positives. However, the MRI was still worth it in my case as it identified the satellite tumor hiding behind the known tumor and it's definitely better to know about that prior to surgery. As for the procedure itself, it's completely painless but a little uncomfortable as you will have to lie face down without moving for half an hour or so.  I'm somehat claustrophobic so it kind of helped that I was face down and couldn't see so I didn't actually know when I was in the machine. I made the mistake of eating a large lunch beforehand so that made matters worse as my belly felt so bloated. I'd suggest not eating for a couple of hours prior to the procedure. As for the IV. I think generally the breasts are imaged first without contrast, then reimaged with contrast. They will put an IV in your arm before they start and the contrast solutions (gadolinium) will be released half way through. I didn't feel this and there were no after effects from the dye. They do tell you to drink lots of water afterwards to flush it out of your system. If you are feeling anxious, I'd suggest that you have your doctor give you an Rx for an anti-anxiety medication but if do take something like that, have someone drive you. Also wear comfortable clothing. You will need to remove your top and bra and put on a gown but can leave the rest of your clothes on unless there are zippers or metal buttons. It's kind of comforting to be wearing your own clothes. Ask for headphones so it will block out some of the noise of the machine, it makes a banging noise which can be disconcerting if it's your first time having an MRI.
